I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  This knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help the government implement 
the Ease of Doing Business and Efficient Government Service Delivery Act, 2018 (Republic Act 
No. 11032) by procuring a modern, web-based corporate registration system (CRS) through a 
license agreement.1 The new CRS will help the government simplify the process and cut the time 
needed to register a business and reduce corruption, in line with the Revised Corporation Code 
Act, 2019 (Republic Act No. 11232). The new CRS will also improve the Philippines’ overall 
ranking in the World Bank’s Doing Business report. This will encourage business formation and 
investment, leading to increased employment and reduced poverty. The TA, which was requested 
by  the  government,  is  included  in the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  country  operations 
business plan for 2020 and is consistent with the ADB country partnership strategy, 2018–2023, 
for the Philippines through the crosscutting theme of private sector development, specifically by 
promoting ease of doing business; and is included in the ADB country operations business plan 
for 2020.2 The TA is also consistent with ADB’s Strategy 2030, as it will (i) address remaining 
poverty and reduce inequalities by facilitating job creation, and (ii) strengthen governance and 
institutional capacity of the Securities and Exchange Commission  (SEC) of the Philippines.3 
  
II.  ISSUES 
  
2.  The government has long recognized the importance of an enabling business environment 
to drive private sector-led economic growth. In 2005, it created the Public–Private Sector Task 
Force on Philippine Competitiveness to promote a national competitiveness agenda. In 2011, the 
task force was renamed the National Competitiveness Council and transformed into a formal 
oversight and coordinating body. The Anti-Red Tape Act (ARTA), 2007 (Republic Act No. 9485) 
established  service  standards  across  various  specific  areas  of  the  government,  including 
maximum processing times for certain applications. The Go Negosyo Act, 2013 (Republic Act 
No. 10644) was enacted to support and encourage the creation of micro, small, and medium-
sized enterprises (MSMEs). In 2016, the government adopted the Philippine Development Plan 
(PDP), 2017–20224 as the first of four PDPs designed to achieve the goals of AmBisyon Natin 
2040.5 The PDP is based on the government’s 10-point socioeconomic agenda, which aims to 
reduce  poverty  and  achieve  middle-income  status  by  the  end  of  2022  by  improving 
competitiveness and the ease of doing business, among others. The Ease of Doing Business and 
Efficient  Government  Service  Delivery  Act  amended  and  bolstered  the  ARTA  to  reduce 
impediments to business creation and operation. The amended ARTA established a formal 
requirement for government agencies to conduct regulatory impact assessments on proposed 
legislation,  established  operational  oversight  for  the  quality  of  individual  regulatory  impact 
assessments through the Anti-Red Tape Authority,6 and provided for congressional oversight of 
the implementation of the Ease of Doing Business and Efficient Government Service Delivery Act. 
 
1  A CRS is a register of organizations in the jurisdiction in which they operate. Each country’s corporate register has 
different types of registrars, content, purpose, and public availability. Denmark and the United Kingdom lead in 
openness of the information available in a company’s register (https://opencorporates.com/info/about/). 
2  ADB. 2018. Country Partnership Strategy: Philippines, 2018–2023—High and Inclusive Growth. Manila; and ADB. 
Draft Country Operations Business Plan: Philippines, 2021–2023. Manila. 
3  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 5 March 2020. 
4  Government of the Philippines, National Economic and Development Authority. 2016. Philippine Development Plan 
(PDP), 2017–2022. Manila. 
5  Government of the Philippines, National Economic and Development Authority. 2016. Ambisyon Natin 2040: A Long-
Term Vision for the Philippines. Manila.  
6  The Anti-Red Tape Authority is a government agency created by Republic Act No. 11032 (Section 17) to monitor 
and ensure compliance with the national policy on anti-red tape and ease of doing business in the Philippines.

2 
Finally, the Corporation Code was revised in 2019 (Republic Act No. 11232), streamlining the 
corporate registration process.  
 
3.  To implement this reform agenda, the government has directed development partner 
support  to  help  address  the  identified  development  constraints.  ADB’s  Increasing 
Competitiveness for Inclusive Growth Program improved the investment climate, made the labor 
market more inclusive, and helped selected sectors become more competitive.7 The program also 
established the Office for Competition within the Department of Justice.8This program was rated 
 
highly successful, and the lessons learned from it have been incorporated in the proposed TA.9 
For example, an in-depth understanding of institutional capacities, together with proper timing and 
sequencing, are factors for success. In addition, ADB’s finance sector programs have contributed 
to expanding the capital markets and increased MSMEs’ access to formal banking services, 
especially agriculture MSMEs.10 A labor market reform program is providing youth with the skills 
needed to join the labor market.11 ADB is also strengthening corporate governance through 
regional capital market TA.12 The United States Agency for International Development is helping 
to strengthen the judicial system through its Judicial Strengthening to Improve Court Effectiveness 
Program, which aims to strengthen the enforcement of contracts and reduce court delays. 
 
4.  These  efforts  have  produced  tangible  results.  The  Philippines  ranked  124th  out  of 
190 economies in the World Bank’s Doing Business 2019, below Singapore (2nd), Malaysia 
(15th), Thailand (27th), Viet Nam (69th), and Indonesia (73rd).13 Doing Business 2020 raised the 
Philippines’ overall ranking to 95th out of 190 economies compared with Singapore (2nd), 
Malaysia (12th), Thailand (21st), Viet Nam (70th), and Indonesia (73rd).14 Improvements have 
been noted in getting credit (up 52 places to rank 132nd), which reflects increasing coverage of 
the credit registry, the recent adoption of a legal framework to support the use of movable 
collateral, and initiatives to protect minority shareholders (up 60 places to rank 72nd). However, 
the Philippines’ score for starting a business deteriorated (down five places to 171st). To start a 
business in the Philippines, companies must complete up to 13 procedures, which could take up 
to  33  days  and  cost  about  $2,000.  This  situation  compares  unfavorably  with  Malaysia 
(9 procedures and 13 days) and Thailand (5 procedures and 5 days). In New Zealand (ranked 
1st), starting a business requires only one procedure and takes half a day to process. 
  
5.  To start a business in the Philippines, companies must register through the existing CRS, 
which the SEC administers. However, the existing CRS is unable to support the current business 
registration volume within the legislated timelines. For example, the existing CRS processed

business applications within 3 days for only 68% of the cases in 2018 and only 43% of the cases 
in 2019.15 Diagnostics indicate that the existing CRS has design flaws and was not built to handle 
the current volume of transactions. The storage capacity is inadequate, contributing to the large 
backlog of business applications and slowing down processing during high loads. In addition, the 
existing system requires preregistration for a tax identification number (TIN), the Social Security 
System, the Philippine Health Insurance Corporation, and the Home Development Mutual Fund 
(Pag-IBIG Fund). In total, this process takes 13 days, with another day needed to process the 
registration payment.16 The local municipality where the business will be located must also issue 
a business permit. In Quezon City, the issuance of a business permit takes 6 days.17 The applicant 
then finalizes the issuance of its TIN through a manual process which takes about 3 days. The 
remainder of the process is consumed by sourcing printed materials to satisfy the requirements 
of the Bureau of Internal Revenue. Overall, the registration process under the existing CRS is 
overly reliant on manual procedures. The staff of the SEC requires additional technical capacity 
to operate and maintain the existing CRS, as upgrades and development of efficiency measures 
are both challenging. The inability to enforce a zero-contact policy introduces inefficiencies and 
provides avenues for corruption. Beyond the existing CRS, the time required to start a business 
could be substantially shortened through the development of a single-window one-stop process. 
 
6.  Onerous regulations and business start-up processes exact a disproportionate cost on 
small businesses. Making regulations easier to understand and reducing the time and costs 
associated with compliance will help businesses, especially MSMEs, to prosper in their local 
communities and through international trade.18 The growth of small businesses contributes to 
higher  employment,  incomes,  and  well-being.19 In  the  Philippines,  more  must  be  done  to 
 
streamline and consolidate corporate registration and administration. A new, more efficient CRS 
can serve as an anchor for ongoing efforts to improve the business environment, including the 
planned development of a single-window one-stop business registration process, which will 
produce real efficiencies and significantly improve the Philippines’ ease of doing business rating. 
 
7.  Easing impediments to doing business can also play an integral role in the government’s 
strategy to bounce back from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. The extended 
lockdown implemented to flatten the infection rate also extracted a significant toll on the economy. 
The gross domestic product is expected to contract by 7.3% in 2020 down from the  6.0% growth 
originally forecast.20 The April 2020 labor force survey showed the unemployment rate at 17.7%. 
An additional 5.5 million Filipinos are expected to fall into poverty, with poverty incidence 
estimated to rise to 20.7% in 2020.21 To counter the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, the 
government launched an overarching response under the Bayanihan to Heal as One Act, 2020 
(Republic Act No. 11469), which granted the President expanded powers, and the ability to 
“reallocate, realign, and reprogram” the budget as needed. Under this Act, the government plans 
to boost financial assistance to MSMEs though guarantees, direct lending at concessional rates, 
and equity injections. Initiatives to streamline corporate registration, together with the existing

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: inequality reduced, and the nation’s growth 
potential increased by improving the business climate to encourage investments (footnote 4). The 
TA will have the following outcome: environment for business registration improved. The TA will 
have two outputs: (i) CRS improved and (ii) capacity of CRS staff strengthened.22 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Corporate registration system improved. The TA will fund the replacement 
of the current CRS by procuring a modern, semi-custom-designed web-based system using 
cloud-based storage through a license agreement. Transitioning to licensed software will reduce 
the SEC’s need to dedicate internal resources to maintaining and upgrading the system and will 
provide enhanced data security. The TA will also provide for reengineering of the registration 
process by removing unnecessary inputs and steps to ensure that the registration process can 
consistently be completed within 3 days. The TA will increase the proportion of contactless 
registrations, reducing the potential for corruption. As a result, the new CRS will lead to a modest 
reduction in the number of days required to register a business, thereby improving the Philippines’ 
Doing Business ranking. 
 
10.  The new CRS will also serve as the anchor for the government’s ongoing effort to address 
in  a  holistic  manner  the  broader  requirements  for  starting  a  business,  and  facilitate  the 
establishment of a single-window one-stop business registration process (glossary) by linking to 
multiple national government agencies. For example, the government plans to link the new CRS 
to the Bureau of Internal Revenue and the Social Security System to enable the simultaneous 
issuance of a TIN and social security identification number. The new CRS will also be capable of 
functioning as a collateral registry, which could help improve the “ease of getting credit” rating.23 
As the anchor of the single-window one-stop registration process, the new CRS will generate 
even more substantial efficiencies and further reduce the processing steps and time needed to 
start a business.  
 
11.  Output 2: Capacity of corporate registration system staff strengthened. CRS staff 
are key to ensuring the delivery of high-quality services to new businesses. According to Doing 
Business 2019, more than half of the economies that legally mandate training of registry staff also 
define a minimum frequency or duration of such training.24 Therefore, training of registry officers 
should be provided during the installation of the new CRS and continue thereafter to ensure 
seamless succession of staff and expansion of the registry. Recognizing the importance of 
training, the TA will improve the capacity of the SEC’s staff for registry operations, including the 
implementation of any revised organizational and operational procedures. The TA will also 
support  the  development  of  a  recurring  registry  training  program  with  a  train-the-trainer 
component. 
 
22 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
23 The Personal Property Security Act (Republic Act No. 11057) was approved on 24 July 2017. 
24 In the People’s Republic of China and Romania, for example, mandatory training programs are held annually.

5 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,000,000, of which $1,750,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 2. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of 
staff support, office accommodation, office supplies, secretarial assistance, and other in-kind 
contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The Department of Finance will be the executing agency and the SEC will be the 
implementing agency. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions.25 The Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction identifies several ineligible expenses: 
(i) purchase of vehicles; (ii) salaries for civil servants; (iii) foreign travel; (iv) scholarships or long 
internships; (v) detailed engineering design; (vi) civil works or other related expenses; and  
(vii) those under ADB’s List of Ineligible Items (or Negative List) and Prohibited Investment 
Activities List.26 The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

14.  Websites. The SEC currently operates its existing CRS via a website. After the completion 
of the TA, the SEC will continue to operate this website although the registry will run using licensed 
software and cloud-based remote storage. The TA will cover 2 years of license and maintenance 
fees after which the SEC will budget for and pay these fees through the fees generated by the 
corporate registration process. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development  Bank  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$1,750,000 to the Government of the Philippines to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan 
Fund for Poverty Reduction for Upgrading and Enhancing the Corporate Registration System, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.
